thread.title: 'Jew Jew Train' among sick lyrics of Britain's most extreme right-wing bands revealed in hate report
thread.title_full: 'Jew Jew Train' among sick lyrics of Britain's most extreme right-wing bands revealed in hate report

author: Nicholas Bieber
title: 'Jew Jew Train' among sick lyrics of Britain's most extreme right-wing bands revealed in hate report
text:
Redneck 28 have been named among the most extreme bands in Britain (Photo: Wales Online) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Twelve far-right bands have been revealed as 'the most influential groups and individuals disseminating hate in Britain'. 
Charity Hope Not Hate has named the extreme bands that are part of a growing hate-based music scene in the State of Hate report 2017. 
Sickening lyrics in some of the songs performed by the bands include 'Jew Jew Train', 'Ain't No Black' and 'N s Love Chicken'. 
Redneck 28, from Swansea, and Section 88, from Farnborough, have been found to be 'two of the most racist bands' in Britain. Read More Neo-Nazi Brit who thought Adolf Hitler was 'God' and posed with knife by Union Jack jailed under terror laws 
Among the sickening lyrics performed by Redneck 28 include 'Jew Jew Train', while Section 88 have recorded a CD which was titled 'Ain't No Black'. 
The report claims members of both these bands were present during the violent fascist demonstration in Dover in January that resulted in more than 60 far right supporters being jailed. 
Other bands named in the report include Brutal Attack, Embers of an Empire and Curfew, which are all based in London. Blackout are located in Wales and Nemesis in Scotland. 
Legion of St George are based in Berkshire & Sussex, Whitelaw are in Heanor, Prime Suspects in Southampton, March or Die in Yorkshire, and Squadron in Kent. Read More Muslim man claims he has been pulled aside at airports 42 times in three years because of 'Islamophobia' 
According to Wales Online , in October it was confirmed Redneck 28 were investigated by South Wales Police after their lead singer, Chris Lewis, performed at an event in Budapest last year wearing a KKK hood. 
The band also posed next to Ku Klux Klan members who 'lynched' a golly puppet at a far right demonstration in 2013. 
In addition to borrowing the controversial imagery of the American South, the band’s lyrics also include multiple references to Nazism and white power. 
In one song, they sing: “This is our land in which we are proud, we will stand and fight and raise our right hand, Sieg Heil, Sieg Heil.” 
The four-piece’s back catalogue also contains songs supporting the Holocaust and about lynching black people. 
You can see the full State of Hate report here: http://www.hopenothate.org.uk/features/state-of-hate/ Like us on Facebook
